title: Joel Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Joel chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Joel Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Joel Chapter 2.

questions.question: What sound is commanded to be blown in Zion according to Joel 2:1?
options: The trumpet
The flute
The horn
The drum
questions.correctAnswer: The trumpet
questions.explanation: Joel 2:1 commands to 'Blow ye the trumpet in Zion, and sound an alarm in my holy mountain'.

questions.question: Joel 2:2 describes the day of the LORD as a day of what?
options: Darkness and gloominess
Light and joy
Peace and prosperity
Rain and harvest
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness and gloominess
questions.explanation: Joel 2:2 describes it as 'A day of darkness and of gloominess, a day of clouds and of thick darkness'.

questions.question: In Joel 2:3, what is said to devour before them?
options: A fire
A flood
A sword
A storm
questions.correctAnswer: A fire
questions.explanation: Joel 2:3 says 'A fire devoureth before them; and behind them a flame burneth'.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:4, the appearance of the people is compared to what?
options: Horses
Lions
Eagles
Waves
questions.correctAnswer: Horses
questions.explanation: Joel 2:4 states 'The appearance of them is as the appearance of horses; and as horsemen, so shall they run.'

questions.question: What noise do the people make as they leap, according to Joel 2:5?
options: Noise of chariots
Noise of thunder
Noise of trumpets
Noise of waterfalls
questions.correctAnswer: Noise of chariots
questions.explanation: Joel 2:5 says 'Like the noise of chariots on the tops of mountains shall they leap'.

questions.question: What shall happen to the sun and moon before the great day of the LORD as described in Joel 2:10?
options: They shall be dark
They shall shine brighter
They shall move backwards
They shall disappear
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be dark
questions.explanation: Joel 2:10 says 'the sun and the moon shall be dark, and the stars shall withdraw their shining'.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:12, how should people turn to the LORD?
options: With all your heart
With your hands
With your possessions
With your words only
questions.correctAnswer: With all your heart
questions.explanation: Joel 2:12 says 'turn ye even to me with all your heart, and with fasting, and with weeping, and with mourning'.

questions.question: Joel 2:13 tells us to rend what, not our garments?
options: Your heart
Your clothes
Your hair
Your hands
questions.correctAnswer: Your heart
questions.explanation: Joel 2:13 says 'And rend your heart, and not your garments'.

questions.question: Who are called to assemble according to Joel 2:16?
options: The elders, children, and those that suck the breasts
Only the priests
Only the kings
Only the warriors
questions.correctAnswer: The elders, children, and those that suck the breasts
questions.explanation: Joel 2:16 says 'Gather the people, sanctify the congregation, assemble the elders, gather the children, and those that suck the breasts'.

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2:17 commands the priests to weep between the porch and the altar.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joel 2:17 says 'Let the priests, the ministers of the LORD, weep between the porch and the altar'.

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2:21 tells the land to fear and be afraid.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joel 2:21 says 'Fear not, O land; be glad and rejoice', which is the opposite of fearing and being afraid.

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2:28 promises the pouring out of God's spirit upon all flesh.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Joel 2:28 says 'I will pour out my spirit upon all flesh'.

questions.question: Complete this verse from Joel 2:25: 'And I will restore to you the years that the ______ hath eaten.'
options: locust
wolf
lion
eagle
questions.correctAnswer: locust
questions.explanation: Joel 2:25 states 'And I will restore to you the years that the locust hath eaten'.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:30, what will God show in the heavens and the earth?
options: Wonders of blood, fire, and pillars of smoke
Rain and thunder
Peace and prosperity
Angels and miracles
questions.correctAnswer: Wonders of blood, fire, and pillars of smoke
questions.explanation: Joel 2:30 states 'And I will shew wonders in the heavens and in the earth, blood, and fire, and pillars of smoke'.

questions.question: What will happen to those who call on the name of the LORD as per Joel 2:32?
options: They shall be delivered
They shall be punished
They shall be ignored
They shall be questioned
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be delivered
questions.explanation: Joel 2:32 says 'whosoever shall call on the name of the LORD shall be delivered'.

medium.title: Joel Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Joel Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with fear about the future and the 'day of the LORD.' Based on Joel 2, what biblical truth would you share to encourage them in faith?
options: The LORD is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and will restore and bless His people.
The day of the LORD is a time only for judgment and punishment without hope.
People must face the day of the LORD alone without God’s help.
The future is uncertain, so we should not trust in God’s promises.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is gracious and merciful, slow to anger, and will restore and bless His people.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:12-13 teaches God’s gracious and merciful nature, urging repentance. Joel 2:18-19 shows God’s pity and promise to bless. Joel 2:21 encourages rejoicing in the LORD’s great works.

questions.question: How does Joel 2 teach us about humility and repentance in times of trial?
options: Turn to God with all your heart, fasting, weeping, and mourning, and rend your heart, not your garments.
Ignore your problems and trust that they will disappear on their own.
Wear outward signs of mourning without changing your heart.
Rely on your own strength to overcome trials without seeking God.
questions.correctAnswer: Turn to God with all your heart, fasting, weeping, and mourning, and rend your heart, not your garments.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:12-13 calls for sincere repentance from the heart, not just outward ritual, emphasizing humility and genuine turning to God during trials (Joel 2:12-13, 2:15).

questions.question: A believer is struggling with discouragement due to loss and hardship. According to Joel 2, what hope can you share about God’s restoration?
options: God will restore the years the locusts have eaten and provide abundance and satisfaction.
Loss is permanent, and God does not intervene in hardships.
God only blesses the wealthy and powerful.
Restoration depends on human effort alone, not on God’s mercy.
questions.correctAnswer: God will restore the years the locusts have eaten and provide abundance and satisfaction.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:25-26 promises restoration of what was lost and abundant provision, encouraging trust in God's faithfulness during hardship (Joel 2:19, 2:25-26).

questions.question: How does Joel 2 describe the attitude we should have towards God during times of corporate worship and fasting?
options: Gather the people, sanctify the congregation, call a solemn assembly, and fast with a sincere heart.
Fast alone without involving the community or elders.
Focus only on outward rituals without heartfelt repentance.
Ignore the need for prayer and assembly during trials.
questions.correctAnswer: Gather the people, sanctify the congregation, call a solemn assembly, and fast with a sincere heart.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:15-16 instructs gathering the whole community and sanctifying it for fasting and solemn assembly, showing the importance of collective worship and sincere devotion (Joel 2:12, 2:15-16).

questions.question: What does Joel 2 teach about God’s power and justice in executing His word?
options: The LORD is strong and His day is great and very terrible; no one can abide it without His mercy.
God is indifferent to justice and does not act in history.
Human power is more reliable than God’s.
God’s word is weak and often fails to be fulfilled.
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD is strong and His day is great and very terrible; no one can abide it without His mercy.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:11 describes God's power in executing judgment, emphasizing His strength and the seriousness of the day of the LORD, calling for reverent trust (Joel 2:1, 2:10-11).

questions.question: A believer feels overwhelmed by trials and wonders how to respond practically. What biblical virtue related to perseverance does Joel 2 encourage?
options: Trust in God’s promise of deliverance and continue to call on His name for salvation.
Give up because the trials are too severe and God does not hear.
Rely solely on human strength to overcome challenges.
Avoid prayer and fasting since they seem ineffective.
questions.correctAnswer: Trust in God’s promise of deliverance and continue to call on His name for salvation.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:32 promises deliverance for those who call on the LORD, encouraging perseverance through faith and prayer (Joel 2:12, 2:32).

questions.question: How does Joel 2 illustrate the importance of prayer and intercession within the church community?
options: Priests and ministers weep and pray between the porch and altar, pleading for God to spare His people.
Prayer should be private and not involve church leaders.
Intercession is unnecessary because God acts without human involvement.
Only elders should pray, excluding children and others.
questions.correctAnswer: Priests and ministers weep and pray between the porch and altar, pleading for God to spare His people.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:17 shows the role of priests interceding with heartfelt prayer on behalf of the people, emphasizing corporate spiritual responsibility (Joel 2:15-17).

questions.question: What practical lesson about family and community worship can be drawn from Joel 2:16?
options: Gather all generations—elders, children, infants, bridegroom and bride—for solemn assembly and worship.
Only the adults should participate in worship and fasting.
Worship should be limited to individual devotion without family involvement.
Children and young people should avoid public worship.
questions.correctAnswer: Gather all generations—elders, children, infants, bridegroom and bride—for solemn assembly and worship.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:16 highlights the inclusion of all ages and family members in worship, demonstrating the importance of communal and family spiritual life (Joel 2:15-16).

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2 teaches that God’s Spirit will be poured out only on the leaders and the wealthy.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joel 2:28-29 states God will pour out His Spirit upon all flesh, including sons, daughters, old men, young men, servants, and handmaids, showing Spirit is given universally.

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2 encourages believers to fear the land and the beasts because of the coming judgment.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joel 2:21-22 encourages the land and beasts not to fear but to rejoice because the LORD will do great things and restore provision.

questions.question: How does Joel 2 describe the character of God in relation to His people’s repentance?
options: Gracious, merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, repenting of evil.
Strict, unforgiving, and quick to punish without mercy.
Distant and disinterested in human repentance.
Indifferent to the hearts of His people.
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious, merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness, repenting of evil.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:13 clearly describes God’s gracious and merciful nature, emphasizing His readiness to forgive when His people repent sincerely (Joel 2:12-14).

questions.question: Fill in the blank: According to Joel 2:28, God will pour out His spirit upon all flesh; your sons and daughters shall _______, your old men shall dream dreams, your young men shall see visions.
options: prophesy
pray
fast
sing
questions.correctAnswer: prophesy
questions.explanation: Joel 2:28 states that sons and daughters will prophesy, indicating the Spirit’s empowerment for speaking God’s truth.

questions.question: According to Joel 2, what should be the response of God’s people when faced with calamity and judgment?
options: Turn to God with fasting, weeping, mourning, and sincere repentance.
Ignore the calamity and continue in sin.
Blame others without self-examination.
Rely only on human wisdom to escape judgment.
questions.correctAnswer: Turn to God with fasting, weeping, mourning, and sincere repentance.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:12-13 emphasizes turning to God with all the heart through fasting and mourning as the proper response to impending judgment (Joel 2:15-16).

questions.question: What practical teaching about stewardship and gratitude can be found in Joel 2:24-26?
options: God will bless the work of our hands with abundance, so we should praise Him and be content.
Wealth and provision come only from human effort and luck.
Gratitude is unnecessary because blessings are guaranteed.
Material blessings are the only sign of God’s favor.
questions.correctAnswer: God will bless the work of our hands with abundance, so we should praise Him and be content.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:24-26 promises abundant provision and calls for praising God, teaching contentment and gratitude for His blessings.

questions.question: How does Joel 2 teach about God’s sovereignty over nations and His protection of His people?
options: God will remove the invading army and protect His land and people from reproach.
God allows nations to rule without intervention.
His people must defend themselves without divine help.
God is powerless against earthly armies.
questions.correctAnswer: God will remove the invading army and protect His land and people from reproach.
questions.explanation: Joel 2:20-21 shows God driving away the northern army and protecting His people, affirming His sovereignty and care (Joel 2:17-20).

hard.title: Joel Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Joel Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Joel 2:1, what is the primary purpose of blowing the trumpet in Zion?
options: To sound an alarm for the coming day of the LORD
To celebrate a festival
To announce a royal decree
To call the people to war
questions.correctAnswer: To sound an alarm for the coming day of the LORD
questions.explanation: Joel 2:1 states that the trumpet is blown to sound an alarm because the day of the LORD is near, signaling judgment and prompting the inhabitants to tremble.

questions.question: Joel 2:2 describes a day of darkness and gloominess. Which Old Testament event shares a similar description of cosmic disturbance?
options: The plague of darkness in Egypt (Exodus 10:21-23)
The crossing of the Red Sea (Exodus 14)
The fall of Jericho (Joshua 6)
The anointing of David (1 Samuel 16)
questions.correctAnswer: The plague of darkness in Egypt (Exodus 10:21-23)
questions.explanation: The description of darkness and thick clouds in Joel 2:2 parallels the plague of darkness in Egypt, which was a supernatural judgment involving darkness over the land.

questions.question: What literary device is prominently used in Joel 2:3 where the land before the invading army is described as 'the garden of Eden' and behind them as 'a desolate wilderness'?
options: Chiasm
Parallelism
Metaphor
Hyperbole
questions.correctAnswer: Chiasm
questions.explanation: Joel 2:3 uses a chiasm, contrasting the lushness before the army (garden of Eden) with the desolation after them, emphasizing the devastating effect of the invasion.

questions.question: The description of the invading army in Joel 2:4-5 uses imagery of horses and chariots. What is the significance of this imagery in the ancient Near Eastern context?
options: It symbolizes military strength and swiftness
It represents divine messengers
It indicates peaceful traders
It is a metaphor for natural disasters
questions.correctAnswer: It symbolizes military strength and swiftness
questions.explanation: Horses and chariots were symbols of military power and speed in the ancient Near East, highlighting the formidable nature of the invading force described in Joel 2:4-5.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:6, what physical and emotional effect does the invading army have on the people?
options: Much pain and blackened faces
Joy and celebration
Confusion and silence
Fear but no physical effect
questions.correctAnswer: Much pain and blackened faces
questions.explanation: Joel 2:6 indicates that the people before the army are much pained and their faces gather blackness, symbolizing distress and terror.

questions.question: Joel 2:7-8 describes the army's disciplined movement. How does this contrast with typical descriptions of chaotic invasions in other ancient texts?
options: They march without breaking ranks and do not thrust one another
They fight among themselves
They are easily scattered by defenders
They rely on stealth and ambush
questions.correctAnswer: They march without breaking ranks and do not thrust one another
questions.explanation: Joel 2:7-8 emphasizes the orderliness and discipline of the invading army, which contrasts with the common portrayal of invasions as chaotic and disorganized.

questions.question: What cosmic signs accompany the invasion according to Joel 2:10-11, and how do these signs function theologically in prophetic literature?
options: Earthquake, trembling heavens, darkened sun and moon, withdrawal of stars; they signify divine judgment
Rain and harvest; they signify blessing
Wind and fire only; they signify purification
Calm and peace; they signify restoration
questions.correctAnswer: Earthquake, trembling heavens, darkened sun and moon, withdrawal of stars; they signify divine judgment
questions.explanation: Joel 2:10-11 lists cosmic disturbances that are typical prophetic signs of God's judgment and the approaching day of the LORD.

questions.question: True or False: Joel 2:12-13 calls for external ritual sacrifice as the primary means of repentance.
options: True
False
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Joel 2:13 emphasizes 'rend your heart, and not your garments,' highlighting inner repentance over external rituals.

questions.question: Joel 2:15-16 commands the sanctification of a fast and assembly. What is the significance of including 'the bridegroom' and 'the bride' in this gathering?
options: To indicate that all social classes and ages participate in the communal repentance
To focus only on married couples
To celebrate a wedding amid the fast
To exclude children from the assembly
questions.correctAnswer: To indicate that all social classes and ages participate in the communal repentance
questions.explanation: Mentioning the bridegroom and bride in Joel 2:16 symbolizes inclusivity, showing that everyone from elders to infants, and all social statuses, are called to repent.

questions.question: What type of prayer do the priests offer in Joel 2:17 and what is its theological significance?
options: Intercessory prayer pleading for mercy and protection from reproach
Thanksgiving for past blessings
A curse upon the enemies
Silent meditation
questions.correctAnswer: Intercessory prayer pleading for mercy and protection from reproach
questions.explanation: Joel 2:17 shows priests weeping and pleading with God to spare His people and prevent them from becoming a disgrace among the nations, which reflects intercession.

questions.question: Joel 2:18-19 depicts the LORD's response after repentance. Which of the following best describes this response?
options: The LORD will be jealous for His land, pity His people, and send abundant provision
The LORD will destroy the land and withdraw His blessings
The LORD will remain silent and indifferent
The LORD will punish the priests
questions.correctAnswer: The LORD will be jealous for His land, pity His people, and send abundant provision
questions.explanation: Joel 2:18-19 reveals God's compassionate response to repentance, promising restoration and provision to His people.

questions.question: How does Joel 2:25 illustrate the theme of restoration, and which other biblical book contains a similar promise of restoration after judgment?
options: It promises restoration of years lost to locusts, similar to Jeremiah's promise of restoration (Jeremiah 30)
It promises immediate prosperity, similar to Proverbs
It promises new laws, similar to Deuteronomy
It promises conquest, similar to Joshua
questions.correctAnswer: It promises restoration of years lost to locusts, similar to Jeremiah's promise of restoration (Jeremiah 30)
questions.explanation: Joel 2:25's promise to restore years lost parallels Jeremiah 30's theme of restoring Israel after exile and judgment.

questions.question: In Joel 2:28-29, God promises to pour out His spirit on all flesh. How is this passage referenced in the New Testament?
options: It is quoted in Acts 2 as the prophecy fulfilled at Pentecost
It is referenced in Revelation 21 about the new heaven
It is cited in Hebrews about Melchizedek
It is mentioned in Matthew's genealogy
questions.correctAnswer: It is quoted in Acts 2 as the prophecy fulfilled at Pentecost
questions.explanation: Acts 2:16-21 directly quotes Joel 2:28-29, indicating the outpouring of the Spirit at Pentecost as fulfillment of Joel's prophecy.

questions.question: Joel 2:30-31 describes wonders in the heavens and a darkened sun and moon before the day of the LORD. Which New Testament book uses similar imagery to describe the apocalypse?
options: Revelation
John
Romans
Psalms
questions.correctAnswer: Revelation
questions.explanation: Revelation 6:12-14 uses similar cosmic signs—darkened sun, blood moon—as apocalyptic imagery, echoing Joel 2:30-31.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:32, what is the condition for deliverance on the great and terrible day of the LORD?
options: Calling on the name of the LORD
Offering sacrifices
Performing miracles
Fasting and weeping
questions.correctAnswer: Calling on the name of the LORD
questions.explanation: Joel 2:32 states that whoever calls on the name of the LORD will be delivered, emphasizing faith and reliance on God for salvation.

theological.title: Joel Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Joel Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What is the primary reason given in Joel 2:1 for sounding the trumpet in Zion?
options: Because the day of the LORD cometh and is near
To announce a harvest festival
To call the people to battle against enemies
To celebrate the restoration of Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Because the day of the LORD cometh and is near
questions.explanation: Joel 2:1 commands the blowing of the trumpet to alert the inhabitants because the day of the LORD is coming soon. This day signifies God's intervention in history (cf. Amos 5:18, Zephaniah 1:14, Malachi 4:5, Acts 2:20).

questions.question: Joel 2:2 describes the day of the LORD as a day of what characteristics?
options: Darkness, gloominess, clouds, and thick darkness
Light, joy, peace, and prosperity
War, famine, pestilence, and death
Harvest, singing, dancing, and rejoicing
questions.correctAnswer: Darkness, gloominess, clouds, and thick darkness
questions.explanation: Joel 2:2 portrays the day of the LORD as a day filled with darkness and gloom, symbolizing judgment and divine wrath (cf. Isaiah 13:10, Matthew 24:29, Revelation 6:12, Exodus 10:21-23).

questions.question: According to Joel 2:3, how is the land described before and after the invading force?
options: Like the garden of Eden before them, and behind them a desolate wilderness
Like a barren desert before them, and a fertile field behind them
Like a peaceful city before them, and a burning furnace behind them
Like a stormy sea before them, and a calm lake behind them
questions.correctAnswer: Like the garden of Eden before them, and behind them a desolate wilderness
questions.explanation: Joel 2:3 uses the imagery of Eden to describe the land's fertility before the army, and desolation behind them, illustrating the devastating effect of God's judgment (cf. Genesis 2:8, Isaiah 51:3, Ezekiel 36:35, Revelation 22:1-2).

questions.question: In Joel 2:11, what is said about the one who executes God's word?
options: He is strong and the day of the LORD is great and terrible
He is merciful and slow to anger
He is gentle and full of compassion
He is weak and needs help from His people
questions.correctAnswer: He is strong and the day of the LORD is great and terrible
questions.explanation: Joel 2:11 highlights God's strength in executing judgment and the dreadful nature of the day of the LORD, emphasizing the holiness and justice of God (cf. Psalm 24:8, Nahum 1:3, Hebrews 12:29, Revelation 6:17).

questions.question: What does God call His people to do in Joel 2:12 as a response to the coming day of the LORD?
options: Turn to Him with all their heart, fasting, weeping, and mourning
Build altars and offer sacrifices
Gather weapons and prepare for war
Sing songs of praise and rejoice
questions.correctAnswer: Turn to Him with all their heart, fasting, weeping, and mourning
questions.explanation: Joel 2:12 urges heartfelt repentance as the proper response to God's impending judgment, reflecting themes of contrition found in 2 Chronicles 7:14, Jonah 3:5-10, Psalm 34:18, and Matthew 4:17.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:13, what kind of God are we called to turn to?
options: Gracious, merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness
Jealous, wrathful, and unforgiving
Distant, unknowable, and severe
Indifferent and passive
questions.correctAnswer: Gracious, merciful, slow to anger, and of great kindness
questions.explanation: Joel 2:13 describes God's character emphasizing His grace and mercy, consistent with Exodus 34:6, Nehemiah 9:17, Psalm 103:8, and Ephesians 2:4.

questions.question: What is the purpose of sanctifying a fast and calling a solemn assembly as stated in Joel 2:15?
options: To seek the LORD's mercy and avert His judgment
To celebrate the harvest and give thanks
To prepare for battle against enemies
To inaugurate a new king
questions.correctAnswer: To seek the LORD's mercy and avert His judgment
questions.explanation: Joel 2:15 calls for communal repentance and humility to appeal to God's mercy, paralleling traditions in Leviticus 23:27, Ezra 8:21-23, Nehemiah 9:1-3, and Acts 13:24.

questions.question: In Joel 2:17, what is the priests' role amid the impending judgment?
options: To weep between the porch and the altar and plead for God to spare His people
To lead sacrifices and burnt offerings
To lead the army into battle
To proclaim victory over the nations
questions.correctAnswer: To weep between the porch and the altar and plead for God to spare His people
questions.explanation: Joel 2:17 shows priests interceding for the people, highlighting their mediatory role similar to Exodus 32:30-32, Numbers 16:46-50, Psalm 99:6, and Hebrews 7:25.

questions.question: What promise does God make in Joel 2:19 regarding His people and the land?
options: He will send corn, wine, and oil so they shall be satisfied
He will destroy the land and scatter His people
He will hide His face and allow enemies to triumph
He will withhold rain and cause famine
questions.correctAnswer: He will send corn, wine, and oil so they shall be satisfied
questions.explanation: Joel 2:19 promises restoration and provision after repentance, echoing God's covenant blessings in Deuteronomy 28:4, Psalm 65:9-13, Isaiah 55:10-11, and John 6:35.

questions.question: According to Joel 2:25, what will God restore to His people?
options: The years that the locust and other pests have eaten
The kingship and political power
The military strength and weapons
The temple and altar
questions.correctAnswer: The years that the locust and other pests have eaten
questions.explanation: Joel 2:25 speaks of divine restoration of what was lost through judgment, a theme found also in Jeremiah 30:17, Isaiah 61:7, Psalm 126:4-6, and 2 Corinthians 1:20.

questions.question: What does Joel 2:27 say will be known by the people after restoration?
options: That the LORD is in the midst of Israel and He is their God
That their enemies have been defeated forever
That the temple will never be destroyed again
That the kings of Israel are divinely appointed
questions.correctAnswer: That the LORD is in the midst of Israel and He is their God
questions.explanation: Joel 2:27 affirms God's presence and exclusive deity, central to biblical monotheism (cf. Deuteronomy 6:4, Psalm 46:5, Jeremiah 31:33, John 14:23).

questions.question: What future event involving the Spirit does Joel 2:28 prophesy?
options: God will pour out His Spirit on all flesh, leading to prophecy, dreams, and visions
The Spirit will be withdrawn from the earth
Only priests will receive the Spirit
The Spirit will rest solely on kings and prophets
questions.correctAnswer: God will pour out His Spirit on all flesh, leading to prophecy, dreams, and visions
questions.explanation: Joel 2:28 predicts a universal outpouring of the Spirit, fulfilled at Pentecost (Acts 2:17-18), consistent with Ezekiel 36:27, Isaiah 44:3, and John 7:38-39.

questions.question: Joel 2:30 describes signs in the heavens before the day of the LORD. Which of the following is NOT one of those signs?
options: Pillars of smoke
Blood and fire
Earthquakes shaking the foundations
Wonders in the heavens and in the earth
questions.correctAnswer: Earthquakes shaking the foundations
questions.explanation: Joel 2:30 mentions wonders like blood, fire, and pillars of smoke, but does not specifically mention earthquakes here, though they appear elsewhere (Joel 2:10, Matthew 24:7, Revelation 6:12).

questions.question: According to Joel 2:31, what will happen to the sun and moon before the great day of the LORD?
options: The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood
The sun shall shine brighter, and the moon will glow like the sun
The sun and moon will both be hidden behind clouds
The sun and moon will cease to exist
questions.correctAnswer: The sun shall be turned into darkness, and the moon into blood
questions.explanation: Joel 2:31 describes cosmic disturbances signaling divine judgment, echoed in Matthew 24:29, Acts 2:20, Revelation 6:12, and Isaiah 13:10.

questions.question: What promise is given in Joel 2:32 regarding those who call on the name of the LORD?
options: They shall be delivered and find salvation in Zion and Jerusalem
They will be judged and punished
They will be ignored by God
They will be exiled from the land
questions.correctAnswer: They shall be delivered and find salvation in Zion and Jerusalem
questions.explanation: Joel 2:32 offers assurance of salvation for those who call on God, a theme consistent with Romans 10:13, Psalm 50:15, Isaiah 12:2, and Acts 2:21.
